scenes.summary: Nick opens with a reflective monologue about his youth and his father’s advice on withholding judgment. He explains his natural tolerance that has led him to encounter many peculiar people and, notably, introduces Gatsby—portrayed as a unique figure whose hope and sensitivity set him apart from the rest.

scenes.location: Nick’s narration of his personal history and the West Egg area
scenes.summary: Nick provides his family background, details about his education, service in the war, and his decision to move East to join the bond business. He recounts the practical matters of renting a modest house in West Egg, contrasts the geography of West Egg with East Egg, and gives his first glimpse of the ostentatious mansion next door—belonging to a mysterious man named Gatsby.

scenes.location: The exterior of an elaborate East Egg mansion (Tom Buchanan’s property)
scenes.summary: On a warm windy evening, Nick drives over to East Egg to dine with old friends. As he approaches the mansion—a stately Georgian Colonial home—he is greeted on the porch by Tom Buchanan, whose imposing physical presence and confident manner immediately sets the tone for the evening.

scenes.location: Inside Tom Buchanan’s mansion – a bright, spacious living room with French windows
scenes.summary: Nick is led into the lavish interior where he is introduced (or reintroduced) to Daisy and meets the other young woman, Miss Baker. The room is filled with light and elegant décor, and the guests exchange warm greetings. The scene establishes the refined yet subtly charged atmosphere of this East Egg social setting.

scenes.location: Around the dinner table in the richly appointed dining/sitting area of the mansion
scenes.summary: The conversation at dinner turns lively and multifaceted. Tom displays his physical dominance and utters grand, sometimes unsettling ideas about social and racial dynamics, while Daisy and Miss Baker offer wry, whimsical interjections. Anecdotes like the butler’s nose and teasing remarks about gossip and engagements further reveal the characters’ complex, sometimes contradictory personalities.

scenes.location: A rosy-colored porch and connecting verandas of the Buchanan estate
scenes.summary: As dinner winds down, the group moves to a softly lit veranda where casual, personal conversations continue. Discussions range from remarks about the longest day of the year and plans for outings to subtle jabs about marital rumors and engagement gossip. The mood is both playful and tinged with tension, leaving Nick somewhat unsettled while the others banter effortlessly.

scenes.location: Nick’s West Egg estate and its surroundings at night
scenes.summary: After saying farewell to his dinner companions, Nick returns to his modest home. In the quiet darkness of his property, he notices a solitary figure emerging from the shadow of Gatsby’s colossal mansion—a man who appears to be surveying the starlit landscape with outstretched arms. Nick’s attention is drawn to a distant, mysterious green light, leaving him with an enduring sense of curiosity about Gatsby and what he represents.
